text: I agree. The advance stuff seems to always be hidden.
Ha! Calling `.append()` is sneakily calling a Java method from HubL and is definitely not supported.
can we at least keep it? :smile:
it def will make a sweet custom piece to what I was playing with
well we probably won’t take it away intentionally since it will break some pages

is there any other things like this we can use? or is there any other kind of super secret hubl snippets that aren't documented? like for media embeds i know there is a HubL code (I cant remember it exactly) that goes something like:
```
{{ video_embed( '[provider]', '[url of vid]' }}
```
speaking of video embeds -- anyone do any embeds using html5 player and have HubSpot host video??
are people using html/visual sitemaps for their HubSpot hosted sites? If so, how are you building them? we’ve been using advanced menus but was wondering if there was a better way.
HAHA <@U3FPXTHH9> I'm asking the same question right now. Working on a client's site -- they are requesting a html sitemap linked on every page
Have you tried pulling in the site map from the sitemap.xml and use javascript to parse it?
I’ve never personally used a sitemap for anything in my life so I was wondering if there is a consensus in the dev community as to their importance?
<@U38EZFVFE> do you have an example of what that parsed sitemap might look like?
LOL..
Nope just an idea to make it work..
You can pull the info in with ajax and parse it as xml instead of json
loop over each instance and do things with that data.
<https://api.jquery.com/jQuery.parseXML/>
I would help you but im pretty busy at the moment
Some people think they are important. Some "programs" or "auditors" determine that each page may need a link to the html sitemap
its an old mentality
the sitemap.xml for google is all I believe you need
your menus on the site should take people where they need to go
This is 100% true, but it doesnt make it less a reality that they want it made. So….
lol. Thats why I made one today lol
So would anybody be opposed to the COS combining, minifying and compressing all the CSS in pages (preserving their order)?
nope.. that HubSpot used http/2 so we didnt need to worry about it so much.
and allowed for cached static files in the design manager.
